content.question: Which of the following progressions correctly realizes the pedal IV64 chord?

choices.label: The figure presents three stacks of quarter notes on a grand staff. The key signature has three flats. The bass notes are E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat one, A-flat 3 and C4 on beat two, and E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat three. The treble clef pitches are E-flat 4 and G4 on beat one, A-flat 4 and E-flat 5 on beat two, and E-flat 4 and G4 on beat three.

The figure presents three stacks of quarter notes on a grand staff. The key signature has three flats. The bass notes are E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat one, E-flat 3 and C4 on beat two, and E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat three. The treble clef pitches are G4 and E-flat 5 on beat one, A-flat 4 and E-flat 5 on beat two, and G4 and E-flat 5 on beat three.

The figure presents three stacks of quarter notes on a grand staff. The key signature has three flats. The bass notes are E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat one, A-flat 2 and A-flat 3 on beat two, and E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat three. The treble clef pitches are G4 and E-flat 5 on beat one, E-flat 4 and C5 on beat two, and G4 and E-flat 5 on beat three.

The figure presents three stacks of quarter notes on a grand staff. The key signature has three flats. The bass notes are E-flat 2 and G3 on beat one, E-flat 2 and C4 on beat two, and E-flat 2 and G3 on beat three. The treble clef pitches are E-flat 4 and B-flat 4 on beat one, G4 and C5 on beat two, and E-flat 4 and B-flat 4 on beat three.

content.answer: The figure presents three stacks of quarter notes on a grand staff. The key signature has three flats. The bass notes are E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat one, E-flat 3 and C4 on beat two, and E-flat 3 and B-flat 3 on beat three. The treble clef pitches are G4 and E-flat 5 on beat one, A-flat 4 and E-flat 5 on beat two, and G4 and E-flat 5 on beat three.

unit.text: 5: Harmony and Voice Leading II - Chord Progressions and Predominant Function

skill.text: Skill 2.E: Use symbols and terms to describe and apply harmonic, melodic, and rhythmic procedures of 18th-century voice leading (up to 4 voices) in notated music.
